summary: This text discusses the biblical figure of Eliseus (Elisha) as a representation of Christ. The name 'salvation of God' is interpreted as referring to Jesus, the Son of God and Savior, while the children mocking Elisha symbolize the Jews mocking Christ on the cross. Eliseus cursing the children who mocked him parallels Christ's actions after his resurrection and ascent to heaven, where he turns to 'curse' the Jews. The text relates this to historical events where two Roman generals, Vespasian and Titus, are said to have brought destruction to the Jews as a divine punishment, symbolizing two bears from the forest that killed the blasphemous children.
